newsitem.title: GERMANY: SAP says Q1 results are on track.
newsitem.headline: SAP says Q1 results are on track.

text.p: German business software developer SAP AG, with its share price rebounding after a tumble last fall, said on Thursday the first quarter of 1997 was running according to expectations.

"We have said we expect sales to grow 25 to 30 percent and pretax profit to increase at a slightly faster rate, by a few percentage points," management board member Henning Kagermann told Reuters at the CeBIT computer trade fair. "So far we see no reason to give the market different indications."
"Today, at the beginning of March, business looks like what we expected, but the next three weeks will tell," he said. "The last month of the quarter always has the most business."
SAP planned to discuss first quarter business at a news conference next week.
The company's shares, which in October plunged about 70 points to around 210 marks after a surprisingly weak third quarter, have climbed steadily since SAP showed a robust final quarter of 1996.
Shares closed in electronic trading on Thursday at 273 marks, down 2.6 marks, as the German blue chip DAX index slipped two percent.

At CeBIT SAP announced a series of improvements to its R/3 software to enable companies to take orders and display product catalogs over Internet. R/3 lets firms closely monitor manufacturing, payroll, accountingand purchasing data.
SAP last year came under criticism from consultants who said the company was moving too slowly to adapt R/3 for the Internet.
The company also announced other features in R/3 that make it easier to customise the software for different businesses.
"In our next product, it will be much easier to pick and choose the modules you want," Kagermann said. "It will be flexible, but you will get a consistent base."
Kagermann said the company had few concerns about results easing in the next few years because of lagging technology investment in Europe, where SAP gets 49 percent of its business.
"I am concerned as a European but not from an SAP perspective," he said. "We are growing rapidly in the United States and other regions."
